results.notes:
Hygrophaneous- brown when whet buff with brown center when dry, bruises blue with green tint at times, purple black spore print, caps slightly umbonate and lumpy planar with age, some very wavy. Separable pellicle. Cap 15-50 mm and stipe 20-50 mm or so.

These were found growing in several large clusters on year old mulch in a landscaped area growing amongst gingo and ivy. Sun obstructed in this area most of the day and a mulched Hill is directly adjacent that provides significant runoff water.

I am not sure if these are caerulescens, caerulipes, ovoideocystidiata, or something different.

results.notes: Being entirely new to mushroom identification, I’m not entirely confident in my ability to discern species; however, I’m somewhat confident this is Lyophyllum Decastes. It should also be noted I’m using “All That the Rain Promises and More…” by David Arora at my on-hand guide. I’ve not tasted nor have I taken any spore prints, though I have another sample to do so with. This cluster was found growing in a bed of mixed mulches underneath several small, dense, shrubs.

results.location_name: Turkey Point, Ontario, Canada

results.notes: I believe this to be a very old Shaggy Mane, or Coprinus Comatus, though I’m honestly not at all convinced. Found by itself in the open of mulch bed, only slightly covered by the tops of several shrubs. It’s hard to tell in the photos but the stem appears to have several of the, what I call “shaggy bits”, that I’ve seen on the several true, young Coprinus Comatus that I have also found in the surrounding areas. I’m still highly doubtful that it is what I guess it to be, but I’m not sure what else it could be at this point in time, as I’ve found nothing (yet) matching it in the guide I use: All That the Rain Promises and More…" by David Arora. I’m entirely new to mushrooms and identification so any help is appreciated!

results.notes:
Fruiting directly beneath Aspen in urban setting. No conifers within 100yards in any direction. This substrate has historically been proliferated with Amanita muscaria subsp. flavivolvata for nearly ten years. This season was dominated by countless true king boletes in varying stages of growth. The classic netted/reticulation, white stems, tan caps and white hymenium(fading/changing to green).

Two fruiting bodies are available for sequencing.

results.notes:
Growing on ground, perhaps on humus, in mixed woods.
Caps up to 9.6 cm across, dry and somewhat velvety.
Gills crowded and subdecurrent.
No distinctive odor.
Spore print light reddish brown and lighter where deposit is thin.
Spores not amyloid or dextrinoid.
Spores ~ 6.0-7.2 X 4.8-5.8 microns, broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid(Qavg = 1.36), and most somewhat lumpy/angular.
Strange combination of characteristics(?)

results.notes:
Two fully mature fruiting bodies flushing between mature Douglas fir and Western Hemlock. This small patch of moss and grass has quite the fungal diversity. Amanita muscaria var flavivolvata, Chalciporus spp., Suillus lakei, Gomphidius glutinosus, Inocybe sororia and Hypholoma species are all intermittently flushing within a few yards of one another in this network of mature coniferous roots(Doug fir/Hemlock). This is the first season to have Grissette’s fruiting. Unusually warm temps this October have made a diverse overlap of species to be prompted into bloom.

I have collected one of the two fruiting bodies and dried for herbarium. At maturity they were both nearly 12inches in height from volva to cap(see added images next to my foot for comparison). Plan to continue monitoring and photographing this unique substrate of mycorrhizal networks throughout the season(and seasons to come). The only saprophyte here are the Hypholoma fasciculare that are most likely infecting an old buried root system from many years ago. We’ll see if the Grissette production(fruiting) continues, slows down or ceases once the Amanita muscaria are in full flush.

Un-earthed the entire fruiting body for herbarium with delicate volva fully intact. Red/orange colorations to the volva upon drying and deeper so with full dehydration.

results.notes: Fruiting in grass between mature Douglas fir and Western hemlock. Multiple Russula brevipes fruiting within yards of this collection. I cooked my “cheesy lobbie” soup with two fresh fruiting bodies. Lobsters love a good treatment of cumin, garlic, white wine, butter and cream and will essentially soak up any flavors you wish to impart with them for cooking. One of my all time favorite fungal species to cook with for soups as they stay firm and hold up to many varying levels of heat.

results.notes: Fruiting prolifically in grass between apple, maple and Douglas fir trees. Very deep, blood red stems(nearly to apex). Fruiting bodies dried and available for voucher. Could be construed as X. chrysenteron, but in my experience the stems are far less red and color only extends slightly up the stem with that species, in addition to the caps being far less red cast throughout(these were nearly maroon w/mature fruiting bodies). Both are edible species, but not the most desirable boletes for the table(IMO).
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Abundant flushes of Pantherinoid Amanita buttons here are most common in early June each season and persist throughout the early summer months. This Fall season has been unusually warm(low 70’s most days) and thus has promoted an interesting overlap with dual season fruiting of both Spring and Fall fungi throughout the greater Olympia, WA area. An example to further this were the huge flushes of Pleurotus pulmonarius that have been abundant over the last few weeks(and still persisting currently). I usually can expect to see one when the other is fruiting, e.g. when I see P. pulmonarius on alders and maples I know to look for Panther’s near my favorite Conifer dominant spots(especially Douglas fir).
I have dried a single fruiting body and stored in my home herbarium for further study and possible sequencing. I know RET is doing a ton of work with Amanita from all over N America and can certainly have a sample if he desires..
results.location_name: B Lot, The Evergreen State College, Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes: Fruiting abundantly from the roots of Acer macrophyllum(big leaf maple). Usually fruiting this size are fresh and occurring early in September but taper off by months end. Unusually warm this year with temps ranging in the low 70’s each day.

results.notes: Abundant fruitings of honey mushrooms were evident throughout the park today(and in many following days throughout Western Washington). Usually this species fruits prolifically(as seen here) in early September and marks the beginning of mushroom hunting season(for me at least). Unusually warm temps(low 70’s most days) in to mid/late October has pushed back flushes of expected species and made for a very slow start for mycorrhizal species such as Cantharellus and Amanita; and has even prompted a few common Spring season species to jump into action around the area(such as Suillus lakei, Pleurotus pulmonarius and Amanita pantherina-although they do occur in Fall months, they are flushing this season as if it were June or July here, currently). Showed harvested fruiting bodies in various stages of growth with this post for comparison and variation.

notes_fields.Habitat: Ridge top, mixed forest, Quercus alba, Quercus rubra, Populus grandidentata, and Pinus strobus present, Quercus rubra was closest
notes_fields.Taste_and_Odor: Taste mild, pleasant, sweet even; odor pleasant, mushroomy
notes_fields.Chemical_Reactions: 5% KOH darkening cap with a faint reddish hue, pitch black on pores, blue grey on flesh; iron salts darkening cap with a grey hue, greyish on pores, dark blue-grey on flesh; NH4OH did not noticeably affect cap color, bright red orange on pores, orangish red brown on stipe where it dissolved the flesh turning brown then grey over time
notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features:
Bolete about 10 cm tall with rhizomorphs extending into the substrate, flesh yellowish brown, staining slightly brown and blue then dark brown, base orange brown
Pileus 4.7 cm wide, 1.5 cm tall, pores .5 cm deep, surface smooth, brown with darker brown to black fibril-like look in the center
Pores .5 cm deep, bright yellow, firm, merulioid, radially arranged, bruising dark brown
Partial veil mebranaceous, thin, attached 3 mm below pores, greyish to blue grey, somewhat translucent, tearing
Stipe clavate, 8 cm long, 2.5 cm wide at the base, 1.5 cm wide at apex
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features:
Narrowly cylindrical, subfusiform to oblong spores, length (8.3) 10.0-13.3 (15), width (3.0) 3.8-4.7 (5.5), Q (2.2) 2.5-3.1 (3.6), 65 spores measured
Basidia with 4 sterigmata, cystidia present, pileipellis a cutis

results.notes:
I cannot identify this specimen. At first I was thinking Paragyrodon, but lots of characteristics were off and the spores are not subglobose. But it does not key out with any Suillus species. It was growing close to an oak, Quercus rubra, as well as an aspen, Populus grandidentata. There were white pines in the area as well.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 172401352 on July 11, 2023.

results.notes: Fruiting later than usual this season by about three weeks(as with many other local annual species due to very high temps for the area-at or above 70 most days in October). A great indicator for the season to come each year, however(as with Armillaria, Xeromphalina and Mycena spp.).

results.notes: Abundant flushes on Red Alder(Alnus rubra) throughout Thurston County recently. Pink tinged coloration on young fruiting bodies-fading to grey with mature specimens. I usually come across(and can expect) these abundant flushes to be common in late May to late June here in Western Washington. This FALL season has had daily temps hovering around 70 degrees and thus P. pulmonarius and A. pantherina have been coming up in our usual Spring season locales with vigorous and healthy flushes. Dried and shipped many collections of this lot to a friend in Texas after dehydration.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes: Growing scattered from soil (I dug to make certain there was no wood underneath) directly under white pine in a mixed pine, oak, maple forest. Caps 3-3.5 cm, golden brown, covered with dense reddish brown granules, solid brown with granules at the center. Plane with a central bump. Gills white to cream, attached, depressed at the stipe, crowded, edges slightly wavy. Stipe 3-3.5 cm long x 5-7 mm thick, swollen at the base and with white mycelia. Granular sheath the same color as the cap and about 2/3 of the way up the stem where it ends in an annulus that seems to dry up with age. Smooth and white to golden brown above the annulus. Spore print white to cream. Microscopy: Spores ellipsoid, smooth, inamyloid in Melzers, 3.6-4.9 × 2.6-3.1, n=30. No cystidia. Scattered clamps in the gill tissue. Cap surface with chains of reddish brown inflated cells.
results.location_name: Cadwell Memorial Forest, Pelham, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, USA

results.notes:
Agaricoid approaching secotioid, round cap, contorted free gills, partial veil that hasn’t ruptured despite evident maturity, slightly clavate stipe that is orange-brown where eaten by larvae, almond odor.

The gills do not fill the cavity leaving a void that is not thought to be present in A. deserticola or
A. evertens. Also this obs has distinct cap context and partial veil whereas A. deserticola and A. evertens apparently lack both. See: https://mushroomobserver.org/330955?q=YdUN

On ground by the side of a gravel road next to wood twigs and piles of needle litter (looked to be pine needles) that were probably dumped at the site as there were no trees in the vicinity. Elevation about 4500’.

Shares macro characteristics of hybrids like Agaricus sp. ‘hybrid’ RWK_2021 and https://mushroomobserver.org/247555?q=YdUN.

Growing abundantly in mulch among Rhus aromatica behind Townshend Hall. Annulus lacking. Veil remants on cap margins. Caps without separable pellicles. Odor not distinctive. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with at least some clamps present. Pileipellis composed of encrusted hyphae. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia abundant, mostly ventricose mucronate. Cheilocystidia measurements from Piximetre: (21.5) 22.1 – 28.1 (28.8) × (7.5) 8.4 – 9.3 (9.5) µm, Q = (2.3) 2.5 – 3.2 (3.7); N = 15, Me = 24.9 × 8.8 µm; Qe = 2.8
Individual cheilocystidia: 23.45 × 9.19 µm, 28.11 × 7.53 µm, 23.76 × 9.20 µm, 25.89 × 8.06 µm, 21.89 × 8.99 µm, 24.48 × 9.49 µm, 26.95 × 9.12 µm, 22.28 × 8.90 µm, 22.10 × 8.67 µm, 22.89 × 9.29 µm, 28.84 × 9.39 µm, 25.76 × 8.43 µm, 21.51 × 9.34 µm, 27.15 × 8.54 µm, 28.18 × 8.60 µm
Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown and subrhomboid in face view. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (5.3) 5.4 – 7.4 (7.6) × (2.8) 3.3 – 4.1 (4.3) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30, Me = 6.3 × 3.6 µm; Qe = 1.7
Individual spores: 7.40 × 3.53 µm, 6.73 × 3.35 µm, 6.55 × 3.58 µm, 5.30 × 3.67 µm, 5.49 × 3.78 µm, 6.71 × 4.34 µm, 6.52 × 3.53 µm, 5.85 × 3.81 µm, 5.60 × 3.74 µm, 5.94 × 3.14 µm, 6.39 × 3.79 µm, 5.69 × 3.33 µm, 7.27 × 3.89 µm, 6.81 × 3.67 µm, 5.40 × 3.20 µm, 5.32 × 3.47 µm, 5.40 × 3.33 µm, 5.86 × 3.68 µm, 6.26 × 3.52 µm, 7.36 × 3.80 µm, 5.40 × 2.85 µm, 6.09 × 3.39 µm, 6.09 × 3.57 µm, 7.63 × 4.08 µm, 6.80 × 3.91 µm, 5.92 × 3.28 µm, 6.63 × 4.16 µm, 5.83 × 3.59 µm, 7.49 × 3.85 µm, 6.54 × 4.24 µm

results.notes: Three specimens found fruiting in a grassy area near both landscaping pines and spruces. Cap of largest 4.5 cm., stipe 3 cm. Stipe colored like cap except at the apex where it is whitish. Gills close, narrow. Spore print color – light brown. A sturdy, not delicate mushroom.
